title: Arran Coastal Way Walking Route

images.title: Bob Jones / Brodick Ferry Terminal
images.caption: Brodick Ferry Terminal. The CalMac ferry from Ardrossan berths at this terminal and the ramp allows vehicles to be driven off and on.

images.title: Eileen Henderson / Raised beach on south coast of Arran
images.caption: Raised beach on south coast of Arran. Looking eastwards along the line of old sea-cliffs towards Bennan Head in the distance. Beside the rock pool in the foreground is one of the many clumps of irises to be found on this section of the Arran Coastal Way. In the distance, towards the right of the photo, the lighthouse on the island of Pladda is just visible.

images.title: Arran Coastal Way below Torran Riabhach by Leslie Barrie, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Below Torran Riabhach

images.title: Val Vannet / North Sannox Burn
images.caption: North Sannox Burn. The burn is viewed here from the North Sannox Bridge on the A841 coastal road around Arran

images.title: Rocky shore on the Arran Coastal Way by M J Richardson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rocky shore on the Arran Coastal Way

images.title: Mary and Angus Hogg / Barwhin Point, near Maidens
images.caption: Barwhin Point, near Maidens. Viewed on a wild February day, with light snow cover lying at sea level on Arran in the background.

images.title: Lochranza by Andy Farrington, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lochranza at the northern end of the island. Here you can catch the ferry to Claonaig on the the Kintyre Peninsula. There's also the ruins of the ancient Lochranza castle to see here.

images.title: Bennan Head by Leslie Barrie, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bennan Head on the southern side of the island.

description: This long distance circular walk takes you around the coastline of the Isle of Arran off the west coast of Scotland. The fully waymarked walk starts and ends from near Brodick ferry terminal. It is classified as one of Scotland's Great Trails and runs for a distance of about 66 miles (107km). There's wonderful coastal scenery including cliff top views, beaches and rugged sections with interesting rock formations. On the route you will enjoy fine views of Goatfell the highest point on the island. There's also the lovely Glenashdale Falls and the historic Brodick Castle where there's some beautiful landscaped gardens to see. For cyclists there's the Five Ferries and the Isle of Arran Explorer cycle routes to try. Much of these routes are also suitable for walkers.
display_address: Corriegills Road, North Corriegills, North Ayrshire, Alba / Scotland, KA27 8BL, United Kingdom
